G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, "[a] judgment relative to custody or visitation may be modified if the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child."

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Lane, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s continuing jurisdiction under G.L. c. 215, § 6, seeking a modification of the existing custody and parenting time order entered on May 15, 2019, in this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody orders under G.L. c. 215, § 6, G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 60.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody orders under G.L. c. 215, § 6, G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 60.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: - G.L. c. 208, § 31A (requiring consideration of a child’s welfare in light of parental residence and stability).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: In determining whether modification is warranted, the Court must consider the best interests of the child, as articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal case, not a post‑judgment modification case. It does hold that removal must be decided by reference to the best interests of the child and articulates how that standard is applied in the removal context, but it does not speak to when or whether a custody or visitation order should be modified. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for a general proposition about when modification is warranted, even though it does contain best‑interests language.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: In determining whether modification is warranted, the Court must consider the best interests of the child, as articulated in Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde is a divorce and original custody/visitation decision, not a post‑judgment modification case. While it clearly states that custody determinations must be governed by the best interests and welfare of the child, it does not address the legal standard or factors for determining whether a custody or support order should be modified. Thus it supports the general ‘best interests’ standard in custody matters, but not the specific proposition about standards for modification proceedings as later articulated in Yannas.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) (‘sole question’ is what is best for children’s welfare).”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s relocation and its impact on the child’s schedule, education, and welfare may constitute a material change of circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects the idea that the custodial parent’s relocation itself (and the resulting change in the child’s routines) can constitute the “material and substantial change in circumstances” required to modify custody. The court holds that a modification of custody must be based on changes other than the move, and reverses the trial judge in part because relocation and a court‑ordered interim schedule were improperly treated as changed circumstances. This is the opposite of the proposition that Massachusetts courts have consistently held relocation and its impacts may constitute a material change.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28…. The record reflects no reason for the order changing custody other than the mother’s motion to remove the child to Rhode Island. The order should not have been made."

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s relocation and its impact on the child’s schedule, education, and welfare may constitute a material change of circumstances.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case focused on the best interests standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 when parents share joint physical custody. It does not discuss modification based on a “material change of circumstances,” nor does it frame relocation and its impact on schedule, education, or welfare as constituting such a material change. The only mention of “substantial change in circumstances” is in a quoted ALI principle, not as a Massachusetts holding, and the court does not adopt that specific rule as Massachusetts law about material change for modification purposes.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: “(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce].... (4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ... including the effects of the relocation on the child.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s relocation and its impact on the child’s schedule, education, and welfare may constitute a material change of circumstances.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, best interests of the child, stability, work schedules, and the harm caused by one parent’s unilateral move and alienating behavior, but it does not frame that relocation as a “material change of circumstances” or analyze any modification standard on that basis. The court cites no Massachusetts relocation/material-change line of cases and instead treats the move and instability as factors in an initial custody determination. Accordingly, it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition that a parent’s relocation and its impact may constitute a material change of circumstances.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge also found that Rose decided to move to Oregon and accepted employment in Michigan, to begin in July, ‘with little, if any, regard for [Jill’s] basic and fundamental needs.’ … In addition to weighing these factors, the judge also assessed the stability each parent offered Jill, as well as the flexibility of each parent’s job. She found that, after the move to Oregon, Jill lived in four different residences in less than one year and had ‘no less than five different care providers’….”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent’s relocation and its impact on the child’s schedule, education, and welfare may constitute a material change of circumstances.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation as a basis for a removal/modification proceeding and evaluates its impact on the children’s lives and best interests, but it does not frame relocation and its effects as a “material change of circumstances” in the doctrinal sense. The only explicit “material and substantial change of circumstances” analysis in the opinion concerns child support and the mother’s remarriage, not relocation or its impact on schedule, education, or welfare. Thus, this case does not clearly stand for the proposition that Massachusetts courts have consistently held relocation and its impact constitute a material change of circumstances.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. At the time of the modification trial, the judge found that the father’s income had modestly increased, and that the mother’s income remained at zero. The judge further found, however, that the mother now receives estimated contributions from her new husband in the amount of $1,000 per week. Based on those changes… the judge reduced the father’s child support obligation….

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The standard articulated in Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)—requiring a showing that the modification serves the child’s best interests in light of changed circumstances—is satisfied by the facts above.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: Schechter articulates and applies the general standard that custody and visitation decisions (and their modification) must serve the child’s best interests, often in light of abuse and changed circumstances. However, the opinion here deals with initial divorce, custody, visitation, and removal orders, not with a later modification proceeding or an explicit standard for modifying prior orders based on changed circumstances. Thus, while it confirms the best-interests framework, it does not itself decide that a particular set of ‘facts above’ satisfies any Schechter-based modification standard.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child. … ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … [A] judge is authorized … to suspend any visitation by the other parent when it is determined that visitation would not be in the best interests of the child. … In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: - Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (best interests assessment focuses on child’s welfare and stability);
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court repeatedly explains that the governing standard in custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) is the ‘best interests of the child’ and explicitly frames that inquiry in terms of the child’s welfare and, in particular, the importance of stability and continuity in the child’s living arrangements and caregiving relationships. The opinion emphasizes that preserving satisfactory existing arrangements and avoiding unnecessary disruption is ordinarily in the child’s best interests, thus directly supporting the proposition that the best interests assessment focuses on the child’s welfare and stability.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In most cases, however, if the child has been living with one parent for some time, the child’s needs are being adequately met under that parent’s care, and that parent is capable of continuing to care for the child, it is not in the child’s best interests to disrupt that successful arrangement. Rather, it is in the child’s best interests to preserve it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: - Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (geographical changes and disruptions to schooling constitute material change);
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for determining child custody (best interests of the child) and the need for findings comparing parental environments. It does not mention geographical changes, relocation, disruptions to schooling, or treat such circumstances as a material change. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition that geographical changes and disruptions to schooling constitute a material change.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being."

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: - Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998) (paramount concern is child’s best interests);
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the controlling inquiry after a finding of parental unfitness as determining what is in the child’s best interests, under the governing adoption statute. The court repeatedly describes the judge’s task as weighing competing adoption plans to decide which serves the child’s best interests and treats that standard as central and dispositive, thereby supporting the proposition that the paramount concern is the child’s best interests in such proceedings.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’"
